sn47.26:1.1: At one time the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, and Anuruddha were staying near Sāketa, in the Thorny Wood.
sn47.26:1.2: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Anuruddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn47.26:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to Anuruddha:
sn47.26:1.4: “Reverend, they speak of the one called ‘a trainee’.
sn47.26:1.6: “Reverends, a trainee is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.26:2.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn47.26:2.3: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.26:2.5: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn47.26:2.6: A trainee is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”
